title: 5 cheap ways to travel more and save money on holidays in 2017
text:

“When preparing to travel, lay out all your clothes and all your money. Then take half the clothes and twice the money,” said the author Susan Heller. 
If you’re planning to travel more in 2017 then you probably assume it’s a New Year’s Resolution that’s going to cost you. 
But there are ways to travel more on a shoestring budget – and here are our top tips… 1. Book at the right time Want to save - then set at least one reminder 
You might think that planning your trip early is the best way to get the cheapest tickets, but that’s not always true. In fact, research from airfare comparison website Skyscanner.com suggests that the cheapest time to book a flight into Europe is five weeks before the journey. 
If it’s train tickets that you want then there are usually a handful of cheap seats for each journey and these can be released about 12 weeks before the day of travel. 
You can sign up to receive alerts via websites like thetrainline.com. Here's how to save more money on train tickets . 
And it goes without saying that if you’re childfree then booking travel during term time can make for a much cheaper (and probably quieter) trip. 
Of course, if all you want is an adventure and you’re not fussy where you go then there may be some real travel bargains available at the very last minute. Read More 2. Ditch hotels Sleeping bags not required (although might help, if you're OK with them) 
If you’re really travelling for the experience then you may not need a dedicated hotel room, with individually wrapped soaps and a hefty bill. 
In fact, staying in people’s homes can be a far cheaper and more genuine way to experience a country. It can also mean you get a local’s perspective on the best value places to see, which can save you a packet. 
Some people advertise their homes for bed-and-breakfast, others simply advertise a sofa bed via websites like Airbnb. 3. Buy travel insurance 'As she fell backwards through the air, Mary idly wondered where her travel insurance forms were...' 
Not to be too boring when you’re planning your wild adventure, but buying travel insurance is essential. 
If you break your leg halfway up a mountain then you really don’t want to be left footing the bill for getting helicoptered to hospital. 
And don’t assume you can rely on your European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). You should get one before heading into mainland Europe – they are free and entitle you to receive state medical care - but in some countries patients are expected to pay towards their treatment. 
Not only that, but your EHIC won’t cover the cost of mountain rescue, lost baggage or being flown back to the UK. Insurance is a must. Here's our guide to picking the right policy for you . Read More EHIC renewal - Can you still get a new European Health Insurance Card, what does it REALLY cover and how long will it work for? 4. Buy a guide book You'd be amazed what you find in side streets, that is unless you have a guide book to tell you... 
Wandering around a strange city with no real plans can be very expensive, so it’s often worth investing in a guide book. 
The very best guides will tell you how expensive various restaurants, attractions and bars are, helping you to avoid the money pits and sample the real culture. 
And remember that it’s worth prioritising experiences you can’t get at home. There are fancy restaurants back in the UK, don’t waste money on generic luxuries. 5. Travel with a partner If for no other reason than to have someone to talk to in the queues 
Often a double room costs just a little more than a single, while splitting the cost of taxis, guidebooks and food can bring the cost per person right down. 
Not only that, but it can be safer to travel with someone you trust to watch your back and help keep an eye on your stuff. Just be sure your travel partner is someone you actually enjoy being around, because you’re going to see a heck of a lot of each other. 
And you can save money on shorter holidays as well as longer trips with our three-step plan to paying less for trips abroad . Read More
